text.ori_cn: 曰：“道即是良知：良知原是完完全全，是的还他是，非的还他非，是非只依着他，更无有不是处，这良知还是你的明师。”
text.man_en: “The Way is innate knowledge. From the beginning it is perfect. It regards what is right as right and what is wrong as wrong. If we only rely on it with regard to what is right and what is wrong, everything will be correct. This innate knowledge is, after all, your wise teacher. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: He said, "The Way is conscience: conscience is complete, and what is is still his yes, and what is not is still his no, and what is right and wrong is only according to him, and there is no place where it is not, and this conscience is still your clear teacher."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Said: "The Tao is conscience: conscience is complete. If you are right, you should be right, and if you are wrong, you should be wrong. Right and wrong only depend on him, and there is nothing wrong with you. This conscience is still your master."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: He said, 'The Way is simply the innate knowledge of good and evil. This innate understanding is completely unerring; it affirms what is right and rejects what is wrong. It follows the truth unfailingly, leaving no room for error. This innate knowledge is your true teacher.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: "道 "是与生俱来的知识。从一开始，它就是完美的。它将正确的视为正确，将错误的视为错误。如果我们只依靠它来判断对错，一切都将是正确的。这种与生俱来的知识就是你的良师益友。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: “道是与生俱来的知识。从一开始它就是完美的。它认为对的就是对的，错的就是错的。只要依靠它来判断是非，一切都是正确的。毕竟，这种与生俱来的知识是你明智的老师。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 道是天生的知识。从一开始它就是完美的。它认为对的就是对的，错的就是错的。如果我们只依赖它来判断是非，一切都会是正确的。这种天生的知识毕竟是你智慧的导师。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“此处须信得本体原是不睹不闻的，亦原是戒慎恐惧的，戒慎恐惧不曾在不睹不闻上加得些子。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “Here you must believe that while original substance is neither seen nor heard, it is also cautious and apprehensive. Caution and apprehension are not anything to be added to what is not seen or heard.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said: "Here we must believe that the original body is not to see and not to hear, but also to be cautious and fearful, and to be cautious and fearful does not ever add something to not seeing and not hearing.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "Here we must believe that the true nature is originally invisible and not hearing, and it is also originally cautious and fearful. Caution and fear do not add anything to the invisible or not hearing.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said: 'One must believe that the essence itself is inherently unseeing and unhearing, and it is also inherently cautious and fearsome. Caution and fear have never added anything to being unseeing and unhearing.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："在这里，你必须相信，虽然原始物质既看不见也听不见，但它也是谨慎和忧虑的。谨慎和忧虑并不是看不见或听不见的东西的附加物。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生曰：“于此须信，本体虽未见，未闻，亦有慎虑。没有看到或听到的事情，并不能增加任何警惕和忧虑。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“这里你们必须相信，虽然原始的物质既看不见也听不见，但它也是谨慎和忧虑的。谨慎和忧虑并不是要添加到看不见或听不见的东西上去的。

text.ori_cn: 见得真时，便谓戒慎恐惧是本体，不睹不闻是功夫亦得。”
text.man_en: If original substance is truly understood, it will be all right to say that caution and apprehension refer to original substance and that what is not seen or what is not heard refer to effort. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: When you see the truth, you will say that caution and fear are the essence, and that not seeing and not hearing is the effort that is also attained."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: When the truth is seen, it is said that vigilance and fear are the main body, and not seeing or hearing is the skill. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: When true comprehension is achieved, one realizes that caution and reverence are the essence, and not seeing or hearing becomes an effective method.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 如果真正理解了本原，那么就可以说，谨慎和理解指的是本原，而没有看到或没有听到的东西指的是努力。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 如果真正了解了本体，就可以说“谨慎”是本体，“未见、未闻”是精进。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 如果真正理解了原本的实质，就可以说谨慎和忧虑指的是原本的实质，而看不见的或听不到的指的是努力。

text.ori_cn: 〔20〕问：“通乎昼夜之道而知。”
text.man_en: I asked about the sentence about ‘penetrating to a knowledge of the course of the day and night. '
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [20] Q. "Know through the way of day and night."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [20] Question: "It is known through the way of day and night."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: "To understand the principles of day and night is to attain knowledge."
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 我问的是关于'通晓昼夜'的句子。'
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 我问‘通知昼夜之事’这句话。 '
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 我问了关于‘洞察昼夜运行’的句子。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“良知原是知昼知夜的。”
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “From the beginning innate knowledge knows the course of day and night. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said, "Conscience originally knows day and night."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The teacher said: "A good conscience is one who knows the day and the night."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'Innate knowledge is originally knowing both day and night.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："从一开始，先天的知识就知道昼夜的变化。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“本智自始知昼夜。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“从一开始，天生的知识就知道昼夜的运行轨迹。”

text.ori_cn: 又间：“人睡熟时，良知亦不知了。”
text.man_en: I said, “When a person sleeps soundly, even innate knowledge is unconscious. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: And again, "When a man is asleep, his conscience is not known."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Another time: "When a person is asleep, his conscience is unaware of it."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: She continued, 'When a person is fast asleep, even their conscience ceases to be aware.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 我说："当一个人酣睡时，即使是与生俱来的知识也会失去知觉。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 我说：人睡熟了，连先天知识都是无意识的。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 我说：“当一个人熟睡时，即使是天生的知识也会变得无意识。”

text.ori_cn: 曰：“向晦宴息，此亦造化常理。
text.man_en: “It is a general law in the universe that when it gets dark, things rest.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Said: "To the obscure feast and rest, this is also the common sense of creation.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: He said: "Feasting in darkness is a common law of nature.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: He said, 'As dusk approaches, it is time for rest; this too is the natural order of things.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: "天一黑，万物休眠，这是宇宙的普遍规律。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: “天黑了，万物就会休息，这是宇宙的普遍法则。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 在宇宙中有一个普遍的规律，那就是天一黑，万物就休息。

text.ori_cn: 夜来天地混沌，形色俱泯，人亦耳目无所睹闻，众窍俱翕，此即良知收歛凝一时。
text.man_en: As night falls, heaven and earth become an undifferentiated state. Forms and colors all disappear. With man also, the ears hear nothing, the eyes see nothing, and all the apertures are closed. This is the time when innate knowledge is collected and concentrated.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: At night, heaven and earth are chaotic, all forms and colours are lost, and people have nothing to see or hear, and all the orifices are open and closed, which means that the conscience is restrained and condensed for a while.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: At night, the sky and the earth are in chaos, all forms and colors are gone, people have nothing to see or hear, and all the orifices are dimmed. This is when conscience converges and condenses for a moment.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: At night, the world becomes chaotic, shapes and colors vanish, and people can neither see nor hear anything. All senses seem to converge, this is precisely the moment when innate knowledge gathers and condenses into one.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 夜幕降临，天地变成了无差别的状态。形体和色彩全部消失。人也是如此，耳不闻，目不见，万窍皆闭。这是先天知识被收集和集中的时刻。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 夜幕降临，天地变得无差别的状态。形状和颜色全部消失。人也是如此，耳朵听不见，眼睛看不到，所有的孔洞都关闭了。这是先天知识被收集和集中的时期。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 夜幕降临，天地变成一片混沌。形态和颜色都消失了。对于人来说，耳不闻，眼不见，所有感官都关闭。这是先天知识汇聚和集中之时。

text.ori_cn: 天地既开、庶物露生，人亦耳目有所睹闻，众窍俱辟，此即良知妙用发生时。
text.man_en: As heaven and earth open up again, all the myriad things reveal themselves and grow. With man also, the ears and eyes now see and hear, and all apertures are open. This is the time when the wonderful functioning of innate knowledge starts.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: When heaven and earth open up, when things are born, and when people have eyes and ears to see and hear, and when all the orifices are opened up, this is the time when the wonderful use of conscience occurs.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: When the heaven and the earth are opened, common things come into being, people also see and hear with their ears and eyes, and all their apertures are opened. This is when the wonderful use of good knowledge occurs.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: With the opening of heaven and earth, myriad things came into being. Humans too began to see and hear, all faculties were awakened, and this is when the marvelous function of innate knowledge arises.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 天地重开，万物显现，万物生长。同样，人的耳目也开始视听，万窍皆通。这时，与生俱来的知识开始发挥奇妙的作用。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 天地再开，万物显露，生长。人也一样，耳朵和眼睛现在可以看、可以听，所有的孔洞都打开了。这是先天知识开始发挥奇妙作用的时刻。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 天地再度开启，万物显现并生长。对于人类来说，耳目现在可以看到和听到，所有的孔窍都打开了。这是先天智慧妙用开始发挥的时候。

text.ori_cn: 可见人心与天地一体。
text.man_en: From this we can see that the human mind and heaven and earth form one body.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: It is evident that the human heart is one with heaven and earth.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: It can be seen that the human heart is one with heaven and earth.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: It can be seen that the human heart is one with heaven and earth.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 由此可见，人的心灵与天地构成一个整体。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 由此可见，人心与天地一体。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 由此我们可以看出，人类的心灵与天地浑然一体。

text.ori_cn: 故上下与天地同流。
text.man_en: Therefore ‘It forms the same current above and below with that of heaven and earth. '
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Therefore, up and down flow with heaven and earth.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Therefore, up and down flow together with heaven and earth.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Thus, the superior and inferior follow the same course as heaven and earth.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 因此，'它与天地形成上下同流'。'
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 故‘上下同天地同流也。 '
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 因此‘它与天地的电流相通。’

text.ori_cn: 今人不会宴息，夜来不是昏睡，即是妄思魇寐。”
text.man_en: People today do not know how to rest. At night, if they are not in dull slumber, they are occupied with erroneous thoughts and nightmares. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Today people will not feast, and the night comes either to drowsiness or to delusional nightmare sleep."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Today's people don't know how to feast and rest. They either fall asleep at night or sleep with delusional thoughts and nightmares. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: People today do not know how to rest properly. At night, they either fall into a deep, unconscious sleep or are plagued by wild thoughts and dreams.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 今天的人们不知道如何休息。到了晚上，如果他们没有沉沉睡去，就会被错误的想法和噩梦所占据。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 今天的人们不知道如何休息。晚上，如果他们没有沉睡，他们就会被错误的想法和噩梦所占据。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 当今的人们不知道如何休息。晚上，如果他们不在沉睡中，那么他们就会被错误的思想和噩梦所困扰。

text.ori_cn: 曰：“睡时功夫如何用。”
text.man_en: “How can we exert effort during sleep ?”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: He said, "How to use kung fu while sleeping."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Said: "How to use Kung Fu while sleeping."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: He said, 'How should you apply your effort while sleeping?'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: "睡眠时如何用力？"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: “睡觉时怎样才能发力呢？”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 我们如何在睡觉时付出努力？

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“知昼即知夜矣。
text.man_en: “To know day is to know night.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said, "Knowing the day means knowing the night.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "Knowing the day means knowing the night.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman says, 'To know the day is to know the night.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: "认识白天就是认识黑夜。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: “了解白天就了解夜晚。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 要了解白天，就要了解黑夜。

text.ori_cn: 日间良知是顺应无滞的，夜间良知即是收歛凝一的，有梦即先兆。”
text.man_en: In the daytime, innate knowledge responds smoothly without any impediment. Although at night, innate knowledge is collected and concentrated, when there is a dream, it already shows some sign of things to come. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The conscience of the day is obedient without stagnation, and the conscience of the night is that which is compacted and condensed, and a dream is a harbinger of things to come."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: During the day, the conscience is adaptable without stagnation, and at night, the conscience is convergent and unified. Dreams are foreshadowing. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: During the day, the conscience is smooth and unobstructed; at night, it becomes focused and concentrated. Dreams are omens.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 在白天，先天知识的反应是顺畅的，没有任何阻碍。虽然在夜间，先天知识会被收集起来并集中起来，但当做梦时，它已经预示了将要发生的事情。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 白天，本识反应顺畅，没有任何阻碍。虽然在晚上，先天的知识会被收集和集中，但当有梦时，它已经显示出一些即将发生的事情的迹象。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 白天的时候，先天知识反应顺畅，没有任何障碍。虽然在夜间，先天知识被收集和集中，但当有梦时，它已经显示出一些未来的迹象。

text.ori_cn: 〔21〕又曰：“良知在夜气发的方是本体，以其无物欲之杂也。
text.man_en: The Teacher further said, “Only when innate knowledge operates with the restorative power of the night is it in its original substance, because then it is free from the impurity of material desires.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [21] He also said: "Conscience is the essence of the party in the night qi hair, in order to be free of materialistic miscellaneous also.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [21] He also said: “Liangzhi is its true nature when the night energy arises, because it is free from the mixture of material desires.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: [21] It also states: 'The pure knowledge that arises in the nocturnal state is the true essence, as it is free from the contamination of material desires.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师还说："只有当与生俱来的知识在黑夜的恢复力作用下运行时，它才是其本质，因为此时它已摆脱了物质欲望的杂质。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生又说：“先天知识只有在夜晚的恢复力作用下，才具有其本来的本质，因为那时它就脱离了物欲的不净。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师进一步说：“只有当天赋的知识在夜晚的恢复力作用下运作时，它才处于原始状态，因为那时它免于物质欲望的污浊。”

text.ori_cn: 学者要使事物纷扰之时，常如夜气一般，就是‘通乎昼夜之道而知。’。”
text.man_en: The student must see to it that when he is busy with or disturbed by things, he always remains as if he is under the restorative power of the night. If so, then he penetrates to a knowledge of the course of day and night. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: For the scholar to make things, when they are in turmoil, always like the night air, is to 'know by the way of day and night.' ."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Scholars want to make things turbulent, always like the night air, that is, "know through the way of day and night." ’. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: A scholar should remain tranquil amidst the chaos of things, much like the serene night air, which is to 'understand the way of day and night and thus gain knowledge.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 学生必须注意，当他忙于事务或被事务困扰时，他必须始终保持仿佛处于黑夜的恢复力之下。如果是这样，那么他就能洞悉昼夜的变化。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 学生必须注意，当他忙碌或被事情打扰时，他总是保持好像处于夜晚的恢复力量之下。如果是这样，那么他就洞悉了昼夜的过程。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 学生必须确保自己在忙于或被事情打扰时，总是保持像夜晚的恢复力一样。如果这样，那么他就能够洞察日夜的规律。

text.ori_cn: 但仙家说虚，从养生上来，佛氏说无从出离生死苦海上来，却于本体上加却这些子意思在，便不是他虚无的本色了，便于本体有障碍。
text.man_en: But the Taoist talk about vacuity is motivated by a desire for nourishing everlasting life, and the Buddhist talk about nonbeing is motivated by the desire to escape from the sorrowful sea of life and death. In both cases, certain selfish ideas have been added to the original substance [of the mind], which thereby loses the true character of vacuity and is obstructed.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: But when the immortal says that the void is from the nourishment of life, and when the Buddha says that there is nothing from the sea of suffering of birth and death, but adds these sub-meanings to the body, then it is not the original colour of the void, and it is convenient for the body to have obstacles.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: However, the immortals say that emptiness comes from maintaining health, and the Buddhists say that there is no way to escape from the sea of ​​life and death, but they add these sub-meanings to the original body, which is not its true nature of emptiness, and it is convenient for the original body to have obstacles.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: However, the Taoists speak of emptiness in terms of health preservation, and the Buddhists speak of emptiness in terms of escaping the suffering sea of birth and death, but if these ideas are added to the essence, it no longer retains its pure emptiness, and thus there are obstacles in the essence.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 但是，道家谈空的动机是希望长生不老，佛家谈有的动机是希望脱离生死苦海。在这两种情况下，[心]的本体都被添加了某些自私的想法，从而失去了空的真正特征，受到了阻碍。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 但道家讲空，是为了滋养长生；佛家讲无，是为了脱离生死苦海。这两种情况，都是在本来的本体上加上了某些自私的想法，从而失去了空性的本质而受到阻碍。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 道家的虚无观念是为了追求长生不老，而佛家的无无观念则是为了逃离生死苦海。无论哪种情况，某些自私的想法被加入了原本的意识实质中，从而失去了真正的虚无本性并且被阻碍了。

text.ori_cn: 圣人只是还他良知的本色更不着些子意在。
text.man_en: The sage merely returns to the true condition of innate knowledge and does not attach to it any selfish idea.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The saint is only returning to the nature of his conscience much less with some intention.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The saint only returns the true nature of his conscience, let alone any other intention.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: A sage merely restores his inherent goodness without any ulterior motives.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 圣人只是回到先天知识的真实状态，而不附加任何私心杂念。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 圣人只是回归本智的本然，不执着任何私心。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 圣人只是回归天赋的本真状态，不掺杂任何私心。

text.ori_cn: 良知之虚便是天之太虚，良知之无便是太虚之无形，日、月、风、雷、山川、民、物，凡有貌象形色，皆在太虚无形中发用流行。
text.man_en: The vacuity of innate knowledge is the Great Vacuity of nature. The nonbeing of innate knowledge is the formlessness of the Great Vacuity. Sun, moon, wind, thunder, mountains, rivers, people, and things, and all things that have figure, form, or color, all function and operate within this formlessness of the Great Vacuity.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The emptiness of conscience is the emptiness of heaven, and the nothingness of conscience is the formlessness of the emptiness. The sun, the moon, the wind, the thunder, the mountains, the rivers, the people, and the things, all of which have their appearances and colours, all of which are used and prevalent in the formlessness of the emptiness.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The emptiness of conscience is the emptiness of heaven, and the absence of conscience is the intangibility of Taixu. The sun, moon, wind, thunder, mountains, rivers, people, and things, all shapes and forms, are functioning and popular in Taixu's intangibility.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The voidness of conscience is the great voidness of heaven; the formless nature of conscience is the formlessness of the great void. The sun, the moon, the wind, the thunder, mountains, rivers, the people, and all things, all forms, appearances, shapes, and colors, operate and flow within this formless great void.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 先天知识之空，即自然之大空。先天之无，即大虚之无形。日、月、风、雷、山、川、人、物，以及一切有形、有相、有颜色的事物，都在这无形的大空性中运行。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先天知识的空性就是性大空性。本来智的无有，就是大空的无形。日、月、风、雷、山、河、人、物，以及一切有形、色的事物，都在这大虚无色之中发挥作用。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 先天之虚是大虚之性。先天之无是大虚之无形。日、月、风、雷、山、川、人、物，以及所有有形、体、色之物，皆在此大虚之无形中运转。

text.ori_cn: 未尝作得天的障碍。
text.man_en: None of them has become an obstacle to nature.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: I have not been an obstacle to the attainment of heaven.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: It is not an obstacle to heaven.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: It has never been an obstacle to heaven.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 它们都没有成为大自然的障碍。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 它们都没有成为自然的障碍。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 它们没有一个成为自然的障碍。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“吾儒养心未尝离却事物，只顺其天则自然就是功夫。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “In nourishing the mind, we Confucians have never departed from things and events. By merely following the natural principles of things we accomplish our task.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mr said: "Our Confucian mind has not been away from things, only to follow the natural nature of the day is kung fu.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "I cultivate my mind as a Confucian and never abandon things. Just letting nature take its course is the skill of nature.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The Master said, 'Our Confucian practice of cultivating the mind has never detached from affairs; simply following the natural order of things is the true skill.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 师曰："吾儒养心，未尝离事离物。只要遵循事物的自然规律，我们就完成了任务。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“吾儒之养心，不离物事。只要遵循事物的自然原理，我们就能完成我们的任务。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“在修养心灵方面，我们儒家从未脱离事物与事件。只要顺应事物的自然原理，我们便能完成任务。”

text.ori_cn: 释氏却要尽绝事物，把心看做幻相，渐入虚寂去了；与世间若无些子交涉，所以不可冶天下。”
text.man_en: Shi Shi wants to eliminate all things, regard the mind as an illusion, and gradually fall into emptiness and silence. If there is no way to deal with the world, it cannot control the world. "
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The Sakyamuni, on the other hand, wants to cut off all things, and sees the mind as a phantom, and gradually enters into emptiness; and if it has nothing to do with the world, it cannot be metallurgical in the world."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Shi Shi wants to eliminate all things, regard the mind as an illusion, and gradually fall into emptiness and silence. If there is no way to deal with the world, it cannot control the world. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The Buddhist seeks to completely sever ties with worldly matters, viewing the mind as an illusion, and gradually entering a state of emptiness and stillness; having little to no interaction with the world, thus making it impossible to govern the state.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 释氏欲泯灭万物，视心为幻，渐入空寂。无以处世，则不能制世。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 施施欲消灭一切事物，视心为幻象，渐渐陷入空虚寂静之中。如果没有办法与世界打交道，就无法控制世界。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 石室想要放下一切，视心为虚幻，渐入空寂。如果没有处理世事的方法，就无法控制世间。

text.man_en: Someone asked about heresy.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [24] Or ask, "Heresy."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: 〔24〕 Or ask: "Heresy."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: [24] Question: 'Heresy.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 有人问及异端邪说。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 有人问异端。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 有人问起了异端。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“与愚夫、愚妇同的，是谓同德；与愚夫、愚妇异的，是谓异端。”
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “What can be understood and practiced by men and women of simple intelligence is called universal virtue. What cannot be understood and practiced by men and women of simple intelligence is called a heresy. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said, "He who is the same as a foolish man or a foolish woman is said to be of the same virtue; and he who is different from a foolish man or a foolish woman is said to be a heretic."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "If it is the same as a foolish man or a foolish woman, it is said to have the same virtue; if it is different from a foolish man or a foolish woman, it is called a heresy."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said: 'To be in agreement with ignorant men and women is called having the same values; to be in disagreement with ignorant men and women is called heresy.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："具有简单智慧的男人和女人能够理解和实践的东西被称为普世美德。不能为简单智慧的人所理解和实践的，称为异端邪说。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“愚人能悟而行者，谓之普德。凡是智力简单的男女所不能理解和实践的，就称为异端。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说，“凡是智力平平的男女都能理解并实践的，叫做普世美德。凡是智力平平的男女无法理解并实践的，叫做异端邪说。”

text.ori_cn: 〔25〕先生曰：“孟子不动心与告子不动心，所异只在毫厘间。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “The difference between Mencius' idea of the unperturbed mind and that of Kao Tzu is exceedingly small.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mr [25] said, "The difference between Mencius' immobilisation and Suzi's immobilisation is only in millimetres.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: 〔25〕The teacher said: "The difference between Mencius's non-motivation and Gaozi's non-motivation is only a few centimeters.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Mr. said: 'The difference between Mencius's unperturbed mind and Gaozi's unperturbed mind lies only in a fraction.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："孟子的'心无旁骛'与高子的'心无旁骛'相差甚微。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“孟子的淡泊之心，与高子的淡泊之心，差别甚微。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说，“孟子的平静心态和告子的平静心态之间的差别极其微小。”

text.ori_cn: 告子只在不动心上着功，孟子便直从此心原不动处分晓。
text.man_en: Kao Tzu directed his effort only to keeping the mind from being perturbed. Mencius, on the other hand, went right on to the understanding that the mind is originally not perturbed.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Su Zi only worked on the immobility of the mind, but Meng Zi was straight from the original immobility of the mind.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Gaozi only worked on the immobility of the mind, and Mencius knew that the mind should not be immovable from then on.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Gaozi focused solely on the aspect of not stirring the mind, while Mencius explained directly from the principle that this mind inherently does not stir.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 高子只致力于使心不乱。而孟子则直接理解了 "心本不乱"。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 高子的努力只是为了让心不被扰乱。孟子则恰恰相反，他认为心本不乱。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 告子只注重让心不被扰乱。而孟子则进一步理解到，心本来就是不被扰乱的。

text.ori_cn: 心之本体原是不动的：只为所行有不合义便动了。
text.man_en: The mind is not perturbed in its original substance. It is perturbed only because one's action is not in accord with righteousness.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The nature of the mind is originally immovable: it is moved only by the fact that there is an unrighteousness in what it does.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The essence of the mind is originally motionless: it only moves if what we do does not make sense.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The true nature of the heart is inherently still: it only moves when actions do not conform to righteousness.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 心灵的本体并没有受到干扰。它之所以受到干扰，只是因为一个人的行为不符合正义。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 心的本来本质不受干扰。只因自己的行为不符合正义，才会感到不安。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 心之本体不动，动则因其行不义。

text.ori_cn: 孟子不论心之动与不动，只是‘集义’，所行无不是义，此心自然无可动处。
text.man_en: Mencius did not discuss whether the mind is perturbed or not. He talked only about the accumulation of righteous deeds. If every action is right, there will naturally be nothing to perturb the mind.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mencius does not care whether the mind moves or does not move, but only 'sets righteousness', and all that is done is righteousness, and there is naturally no place for this mind to move.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Mencius did not care whether his heart was moving or not, he was just "collecting righteousness", and everything he did was righteous, so naturally this heart had no place to move.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Mencius disregarded whether the mind was stirred or not, focusing solely on 'accumulating righteousness.' All his actions were righteous, making his mind naturally untroubled.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 孟子没有讨论心是否不安。他只谈了义行的积累。如果一举一动都是正确的，自然就不会扰乱心神。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 孟子没有讨论心是否乱。他只讲积累善行。如果每一个行为都是正确的，自然就没有什么可以扰乱心了。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 孟子没有讨论心是否受到困扰。他只谈论积累正义的行为。如果每一个行为都是正确的，心自然就不会受到困扰。

text.ori_cn: 若告子只要此心不动，便是把捉此心，将他生生不息之根反阻挠了，此非徒无益，而又害之。
text.man_en: As Kao Tzu only wanted the mind not to be perturbed, his effort amounts to holding on to the mind and bending and breaking its root that by nature grows and grows without cease. This not only does no good; it is harmful.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: If the plaintiff does not move this mind, then he is holding this mind and obstructing the root of his unending life, which is not only unhelpful, but also harmful.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: If you tell the child that as long as this mind does not move, it will be to capture this mind and block the root of his endless life. This is not only useless, but also harmful.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: If Gaozi only seeks to keep his heart unmoved, he is actually constraining the very root of his heart’s vitality, thus hindering its incessant growth. This is not only futile but also harmful.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 由于高子只希望心不受扰乱，他的努力等于抓住了心，弯曲和折断了心的根，而心的本性是不断生长的。这不仅无益，反而有害。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 因为高子只求心不被扰乱，所以他的努力就等于抓住心，折断它本性生生不息的根。这不仅没有任何好处，而且还会带来负面影响。这是有害的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 高子只想让心不受干扰，他的努力相当于抓住心并扭曲折断其本来不息生长的根源。这不仅无益，而且有害。

text.ori_cn: 孟子‘集义’工夫，自是养得充满，并无馁歉，自是纵横自在，活泼泼地；此便是浩然之气。”
text.man_en: Mencius' task of accumulating righteous deeds, on the other hand, can naturally be cultivated to the full without any deficiency. It is naturally free and at ease, and is extremely lively and dynamic. This is ‘strong moving power. ' ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mencius' work of 'collecting righteousness' is full of nourishment and no discouragement, and it is free and lively; this is the spirit of hao yan."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Mencius's work of "collecting righteousness" was full of self-cultivation, without any hesitation, and he was free and lively; this is the aura of awe-inspiringness. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Mencius' practice of 'accumulating righteousness' naturally nurtures fullness and without any deficiency, allowing for freedom, liveliness, and vigor; this is what is called the 'overwhelming righteous energy.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 而孟子的 "积善成德"，自然可以做到 "尽善尽美"，没有任何不足。这就是 "强动之力"。这就是'强动之功'。' "
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 而孟子的积义之业，自然可以修得圆满，没有任何不足。自然洒脱自在，极其活泼动感。这就是‘强大的感动力’。 ’”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 孟子的积累仁义之事，自然可以毫无欠缺地培养到极致。它自然自在，非常生气勃勃且充满活力。这就是‘充沛的行动力’。

text.ori_cn: 〔26〕又曰：“告子病源，从性无善无不善上见来。
text.man_en: The Teacher further said, “The source of Kao Tzu's trouble can be seen in his doctrine that the nature is neither good nor evil.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [26] He also said, "The source of the illness of the suzuki, from the nature of no good or no good to see on.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [26] He also said: “The source of Gao Zi’s disease comes from the view that one’s nature is neither good nor bad.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: [26] It also states: 'Gaozi's source of illness stems from his view that human nature is neither good nor bad.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师还说："从高子的'性非善非恶'学说中，我们可以看到他烦恼的根源。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生又说：“高子的烦恼根源在于他的性无善无恶的学说。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师进一步说道：“高子的麻烦源于他的学说——人的本性既不善也不恶。”

text.ori_cn: 性无善无不善，虽如此说，亦无大差。
text.man_en: Since the nature is neither good nor evil, it is not a great mistake to say so.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: There is no goodness or badness in nature; though it is so said, there is no great difference.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Nature is neither good nor bad. Even so, there is no big difference.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Sexuality is neither good nor bad; even though it is said this way, there is no significant difference.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 既然本性非善非恶，那么这样说就不是大错特错了。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 既然性无善恶，这样说也不算什么大错。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 既然人性既不是善也不是恶，这么说也无不可。

text.ori_cn: 但告子执定看了，便有个无善无不善的性在内，有善有恶又在物感上看，便有个物在外：却做两边看了，便会差。
text.man_en: But Kao Tzu looked at the matter too rigidly. Therefore to him internally there is the nature which is neither good nor evil. He saw good and evil in things and the stimulation they give. Therefore externally there is the thing. In this way he looked at the nature from two sides and hence he was mistaken.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: But when Suzi looks at it with determination, there is a nature without goodness and without badness within, and when there is goodness and evil, and when he looks at it in the sense of things, there is a thing outside: but when he looks at it from both sides, it will be bad.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: But when Gaozi looked at it with concentration, there was a nature inside that was neither good nor bad, and there was good and evil. And if you look at it with the physical sense, there is something outside. But if you look at it from both sides, it will be different.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: But if one firmly adheres to the perspective of Gaozi, there is inherently a nature devoid of both good and evil inside. With goodness and badness perceived externally through external stimuli, this results in an external object: considering it this way, one might make errors.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 但是，高子把这个问题看得太死板了。因此，在他看来，内在存在着非善非恶的本性。他从事物及其所带来的刺激中看到了善恶。因此，外在就是事物。这样，他就从两个方面来看待本性，因此他错了。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 但高子看问题太严格了。所以他的内在有不善不恶的本质。他看到了事物的善与恶以及它们所带来的刺激。所以外在有这个东西。他这样从两个方面来看待自然，因此他是错误的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 但是告子对这个问题看得太僵硬了。因此对他来说，内在上有既不是善也不是恶的本性。他看到了事物中的善和恶以及它们的刺激。因此，外在上有事物。这样，他从两个方面来看待本性，因此他错了。

text.ori_cn: 无善无不善，性原是如此：悟得及时，只此一句便尽了，更无有内外之间。
text.man_en: The nature in its original state is neither good nor evil. If we understand it adequately this one sentence covers all, and there is no separation of the internal and the external.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: There is no goodness, no ungoodness; nature is like this: when one realises it in time, this sentence alone is all there is, and there is no more between inside and outside.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: There is neither good nor bad, this is the nature of nature: when enlightened in time, this sentence is all it takes, and there is no between inside and outside.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Neither good nor bad, such is the nature: realizing this in time, just this one phrase encapsulates it all, leaving no distinction between inside and outside.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 本性本无善恶。如果我们充分理解，这一句话就涵盖了一切，不存在内外之分。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 自然本来的状态是无善无恶的。如果我们理解得充分的话，这一句话就涵盖了一切，并且没有内在和外在的分离。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 自然本质上既不是善的也不是恶的。如果我们充分理解这一句话，它涵盖了一切，并且内外没有分割。

text.ori_cn: 告子见一个性在内，见一个物在外，便见他于性有未透彻处。”
text.man_en: Kao Tzu saw the nature as internal and things as external. From this we can see that he had not understood the nature thoroughly. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: When the suitor sees a nature within and a thing without, he sees that he has imperfections in nature."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: When Gaozi saw a nature inside and an object outside, he saw that there was something about his nature that was not fully understood. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Gaozi sees an inherent nature within and an external object without, thus perceives that his understanding of nature is not yet thorough.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 高子认为 "性 "是内在的，"物 "是外在的。由此可见，他对自然的理解并不透彻。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 高子视性为内，物为外。由此可见，他对本质的了解还不够透彻。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 告子认为本性是内在的，事物是外在的。从这一点上我们可以看出，他并没有彻底理解本性。

text.ori_cn: 〔27〕朱本思问：“人有虚灵，方有良知。
text.man_en: Chu Penssu asked, “Man has innate knowledge because he possesses pure intelligence.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [27] Zhu Benshi asked, "People have a conscience only when they have a false spirit.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [27] Zhu Bensi asked: “Only when a person has a false spirit can he have a conscience.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: [27] Zhu Bensi asked: ‘Only when one possesses a clear and open mind can one have good conscience.’
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 朱彭苏问道："人之所以拥有与生俱来的知识，是因为他拥有纯粹的智慧。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 楚本苏问道：“人有先天知识，因为他拥有纯粹的智慧。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 朱彭素问道：“人类之所以有天生的知识，是因为他具备纯粹的智慧。”

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“人的良知，就是草、木、瓦、石的良知：若草、木、瓦、石无人的良知，不可以为草、木、瓦、石矣。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “The innate knowledge of man is the same as that of plants and trees, tiles and stones. Without the innate knowledge inherent in man, there cannot be plants and trees, tiles and stones.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mr. said: "The conscience of man is the conscience of grass, wood, tile and stone: if the conscience of grass, wood, tile and stone no one, can not be grass, wood, tile and stone carry on.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "Human conscience is the conscience of grass, wood, tiles, and stones. If grass, wood, tiles, and stones do not have a conscience, they cannot be grass, wood, tiles, or stones."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'The conscience of a person is the same as the conscience of grass, trees, tiles, and stones. If grass, trees, tiles, and stones did not have the conscience of a person, they could not be called grass, trees, tiles, or stones.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："人之初，性本善，与草木瓦石同。没有人与生俱来的知识，就不会有草木瓦石。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生说：“人的先天知识，与草木瓦石一样。没有人固有的先天知识，就不可能有草木瓦石。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说，“人的先天之知与植物、树木、瓦片和石头的先天之知是一样的。没有人类固有的先天之知，就不会有植物、树木、瓦片和石头。”

text.ori_cn: 岂惟草、木、瓦、石为然，天、地无人的良知，亦不可为天、地矣。
text.man_en: This is not true of them only. Even Heaven and Earth cannot exist without the innate knowledge that is inherent in man.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Not only are grass, wood, tile, and stone true, but the conscience of no one in heaven or on earth can be heaven or earth.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: How can grass, wood, tiles, and stones be natural? Heaven and earth cannot be heaven and earth if no one has a conscience.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Not only is it true for plants, wood, tiles, and stones, but even heaven and earth themselves would cease to be without the innate moral consciousness of humans.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 这不仅仅是他们的真实想法。没有人与生俱来的知识，天地也无法存在。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 这不仅仅适用于他们。如果没有人类固有的先天知识，即使是天地也无法存在。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 这不仅仅适用于他们。即使是天地，也无法在没有人类所固有的本性知识的情况下存在。

text.ori_cn: 盖天、地、万物与人原是一体，其发窍之最精处，是人心一点灵明，风、雨、露、雷，日、月、星、辰，禽、兽、草、木，山、川、土、石，与人原只一体。
text.man_en: For at bottom Heaven, Earth, the myriad things, and man form one body. The point at which this unity is manifested in its most refined and excellent form is the clear intelligence of the human mind. Wind, rain, dew, thunder, sun and moon, stars, animals and plants, mountains and rivers, earth and stones are essentially of one body with man.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Covering the sky, the earth, all things and man is one, the hair of the most exquisite place, is the human heart a little spirit, wind, rain, dew, thunder, sun, moon, stars, stars, birds, animals, grass, wood, mountains, rivers, soil, stone, and man is only one.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The sky, the earth, all things and human beings are originally one, and the most exquisite place of its origin is the human mind's little spiritual clarity, wind, rain, dew, thunder, sun, moon, stars, celestial bodies, birds, beasts, grass, trees, Mountains, rivers, soil, and rocks are all one body with people.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Heaven, earth, all things, and humanity are fundamentally one entity. The most refined manifestation of this unity is the human heart's single point of spiritual clarity. Wind, rain, dew, thunder, sun, moon, stars, birds, animals, grass, trees, mountains, rivers, soil, and stones are essentially one with humanity.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 因为，天、地、万物和人根本就是一个整体。这种一体性以最精炼、最卓越的形式体现出来的一点，就是人类头脑中的清明智慧。风、雨、露、雷、日月、星辰、动植物、山川、土石，本质上都与人同体。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 因为天、地、万物、人，本质上是一体的。这种统一以最精致和最优秀的形式表现出来的一点是人类心灵的清晰智慧。风、雨、露、雷、日月、星辰、动植物、山川、土石，本质上与人是一体的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 究其根本，天地万物与人是一体的。这种统一性在最精妙和卓越的形式中表现出来的点便是人类心智的清明。风雨露霜，雷电日月，星辰动植，山河大地，岩石土壤，本质上与人是一体的。

text.ori_cn: 故五谷、禽兽之类皆可以养人，药石之类皆可以疗疾，只为同此一气，故能相通耳。”
text.man_en: It is for this reason that such things as the grains and animals can nourish man and that such things as medicine and minerals can heal diseases. Since they share the same material force, they enter into one another. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Therefore, all grains, birds and animals can nourish people, and all medicines and stones can cure diseases, just because of the same gas, so they can be connected."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Therefore, grains, animals, and the like can nourish people, and medicines and stones can cure diseases. It is because of the same energy that they can communicate with each other. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Therefore, grains and beasts alike can nourish people, and medicines and stones can cure ailments, simply because they share the same essence and thus can interact with each other.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 正因如此，谷物和动物等才能滋养人类，药物和矿物质等才能治疗疾病。因为它们拥有相同的物质力量，所以彼此相融。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 正因为如此，五谷、动物之类的东西才能滋养人，药物、矿物之类的东西才能治愈疾病。由于它们具有相同的物质力量，因此它们彼此进入。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 正是由于这个原因，谷物和动物能够滋养人类，药物和矿物能够治愈疾病。由于它们具有相同的物质力量，它们相互融合。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“你未看此花时，此花与汝心同归于寂：你来看此花时，则此花颜色一时明白起来：便知此花不在你的心外。”
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “Before you look at these flowers, they and your mind are in the state of silent vacancy. As you come to look at them, their colors at once show up clearly. From this you can know that these flowers are not external to your mind. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said, "When thou lookest not at this flower, it is silent with thy heart: when thou comest to see it, then the colour of the flower is understood for a moment: then thou knowest that it is not outside thy heart."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "When you don't look at this flower, this flower and your heart are silent together. When you look at this flower, the color of this flower becomes clear for a moment, and you know that this flower is not outside your heart."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'When you haven't looked at this flower, it is at peace, just like your heart. When you observe the flower, its colors suddenly become vivid, making you realize that this flower is not separate from your mind.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："在你看这些花之前，它们和你的心灵都处于寂静空无的状态。当你注视它们时，它们的颜色立刻清晰地显现出来。由此你可以知道，这些花并不在你的心灵之外。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 老师说：“在你看到这些花之前，它们和你的心都处于寂静的空虚状态。当你看向它们时，它们的颜色立刻就清晰地显现出来。由此可知，这些花不是你心外的。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“在你看这些花之前，它们和你的心处于静寂空灵的状态。当你开始看它们时，它们的颜色立即显现出来。从这点你可以知道，这些花并不在你的心之外。”

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“惟是道理自有厚薄。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “It is because of principles that there necessarily is relative importance.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said: "But the reason has its own thickness.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "But principles have their own thickness.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'The principles naturally have their variations in depth.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："正因为有原则，才必然有相对的重要性。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生说：“正因为有理，所以必然有相对的重要性。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“因为有原则，所以一定有相对的重要性。”

text.ori_cn: 比如身是一体，把手足捍头目，岂是偏要薄手足，其道理合如此。
text.man_en: Take for example the body, which is one. If we use the hands and the feet to protect the head, does that mean that we especially treat them as less important? Because of their principles this is what should be done.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: For example, if the body is one and the hands and the feet defend the head and the eyes, is it not the case that the hands and the feet are thin?
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: For example, if the body is one body and the hands and feet are used to protect the leader, why should the hands and feet be thin? This is the logic.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: For instance, the body is an integral whole; to protect the hands and feet is to safeguard the head and eyes. How could one desire to slight the hands and feet? Such is the rationale.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 以身体为例，它是一个整体。如果我们用手和脚来保护头部，这是否意味着我们特别不重视它们？因为它们的原则就是应该这样做。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 以身体为例，它是一个。如果我们用手和脚来保护头部，是否意味着我们特别不重视它们？因为他们的原则，这是应该做的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 以身体为例，身体是一个整体。如果我们用手和脚来保护头部，这是否意味着我们特别认为手和脚不重要呢？根据这些原理，这就是我们应该做的。

text.ori_cn: 禽兽与草木同是爱的，把草木去养禽兽，心又忍得：人与禽兽同是爱的，宰禽兽以养亲与供祭祀，燕宾客，心又忍得：至亲与路人同是爱的，如箪食豆羹，得则生，不得则死，不能两全，宁救至亲，不救路人，心又忍得：这是道理合该如此。
text.man_en: We love both plants and animals, and yet we can tolerate feeding animals with plants. We love both animals and men, and yet we can tolerate butchering animals to feed our parents, provide for religious sacrifices, and entertain guests. We love both parents and strangers. But suppose here are a small basket of rice and a platter of soup. With them one will survive and without them one will die. 6 Since not both our parents and the stranger can be saved by this meager food, we will prefer to save our parents instead of the stranger. 7 This we can tolerate. 8 We can tolerate all these because by principle these should be done.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The beast and the grass and the trees are the same as love, and if the grass and the trees are used to feed the beast, the heart can bear it: the man and the beast are the same as love, and if the beast is slaughtered to feed his relatives and to offer sacrifices and guests, the heart can bear it: the closest relative and the passer-by are the same as love, and if they are like a danjang and a bean-soup, if they get it, then they live, if they don't get it, then they die, and they cannot have it both ways, and if they prefer to save their closest relatives rather than save the passer-by, the heart can bear it: it is a truth that ought to be so.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Animals and grass and trees are both loved. If you use grass and trees to raise animals, your heart can bear it. People and animals love you both. If you kill animals to feed your relatives and offer sacrifices, you can be a guest. But your heart can bear it: your loved ones and passers-by are both loved by each other. It's like eating bean soup with a basket. If you get it, you will live, if you don't get it, you will die. You can't have both. You would rather save your loved ones than passers-by, but you can bear it: this is the truth and it should be like this.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Beasts and plants are both loved; if we use plants to feed the beasts, how can our hearts bear it? Humans and beasts are both loved; if we slaughter beasts to feed our parents, to offer in sacrifices, and to entertain guests, how can our hearts bear it? Close kin and strangers are both loved; if, with only a bowl of rice or soup, life and death hinge on having it, and we cannot save both, we would rather save our close kin than a stranger. How can our hearts bear it? This reasoning aligns with the natural order.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 我们既爱植物，也爱动物，但我们可以容忍用植物喂养动物。我们既爱动物，也爱人类，但我们可以容忍屠宰动物来喂养父母、供奉宗教祭品和招待客人。我们既爱父母，也爱陌生人。但是，假设这里有一小筐米和一盘汤。有了它们就能生存，没有它们就会死亡。6 既然我们的父母和陌生人都无法通过这微薄的食物获救，那么我们宁愿救自己的父母，也不愿救陌生人。7 这些我们都能忍受。8 我们可以容忍这一切，因为从原则上讲，这些都是应该做的。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 我们热爱植物和动物，但我们可以容忍用植物喂养动物。我们热爱动物和人类，但我们可以容忍屠宰动物来养活我们的父母、提供宗教祭品和招待客人。我们爱父母，也爱陌生人。但假设这里有一篮子米饭和一盘汤。有了他们，人就能生存，没有他们，人就会死。 6 既然这微薄的食物不能拯救我们的父母和陌生人，我们宁愿拯救我们的父母而不是陌生人。 7 这是我们可以容忍的。 8 我们可以容忍所有这些，因为原则上这些都是应该做的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 我们既爱植物又爱动物，但我们可以容忍用植物喂养动物。我们既爱动物又爱人类，但我们可以容忍为了喂养父母、进行宗教祭祀和招待客人而宰杀动物。我们既爱父母又爱陌生人。但是假设这里有一小篮米和一盘汤。有了它们，一个人能活下去，没有它们，一个人就会死。由于这微薄的食物不能同时拯救我们的父母和陌生人，我们会选择优先拯救父母，而不是陌生人。这是我们可以容忍的。我们可以容忍所有这些，因为原则上这些是应该做的。

text.ori_cn: 及至吾身与至亲，更不得分别彼此厚薄。
text.man_en: As to the relationship between ourselves and our parents there cannot be any distinction of this or that or of greater or lesser importance.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: And when it comes to my body and my nearest relatives, I shall not be able to distinguish between them.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: When it comes to my body and my closest relatives, I can’t even distinguish between each other’s strengths and weaknesses.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Even as it comes to myself and my closest kin, distinctions of favor or bias are utterly impermissible.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 至于我们自己和父母之间的关系，不可能有任何这样或那样、或重要或不重要的区别。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 至于我们和父母之间的关系，不存在任何这样或那样、重要或次要的区别。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 对于我们与父母之间的关系，不应有彼此或重要性大小的区别。

text.ori_cn: 盖以仁民爱物皆从此出，此处可忍，更无所不忍矣。
text.man_en: For being humane to all people and feeling love for all comes from this affection toward parents. If in this relationship we can tolerate any relative importance, then anything can be tolerated.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Covering the benevolent people and love things are out of this, here can be tolerated, and no more intolerable carry on.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Because benevolence, people, and love for things all come from here, there is nothing that can be tolerated here, and there is nothing that cannot be tolerated.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: All benevolence towards the people and love for things stem from here. If one can be patient in this regard, there will be nothing else they cannot endure.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 因为对所有人都要有人情味，对所有人都要有爱，这种爱来自于对父母的感情。如果在这种关系中，我们可以容忍任何相对的重要性，那么任何事情都是可以容忍的。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 仁爱一切众生，爱一切众生，皆出于父母之情。如果在这段关系中我们可以容忍任何相对重要性，那么任何事情都可以容忍。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 对所有人仁慈和爱护都是源于对父母之情的爱。如果在这种关系中我们能容忍任何相对的重要性，那么任何事情都可以容忍。

text.ori_cn: 《大学》所谓厚薄，是良知上自然的条理，不可踰越，此便谓之义：顺这个条理，便谓之礼；知此条理，便谓之智；终始是这个条理，便谓之信。”
text.man_en: What the Great Learning calls relative importance means that according to innate knowledge there is a natural order which should not be skipped over. This is called righteousness. To follow this order is called propriety. To understand this order is called wisdom. And to follow this order from beginning to end is called faithfulness. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The so-called thickness of the University is the natural order of conscience, which must not be transgressed, and this is called righteousness: to be obedient to this order is called propriety; to know this order is called wisdom; and to be always of this order is called faith."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The so-called thick and thin in "The Great Learning" refers to the natural order of conscience, which cannot be transcended. This is called meaning: following this order is called etiquette; knowing this order is called wisdom; always following this order is called faith. . "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: As mentioned in 'The Great Learning,' the concepts of thickness and thinness (in moral sense) are natural principles inherent in our conscience that cannot be overstepped. This is called 'righteousness': following this principle is called 'propriety'; knowing this principle is called 'wisdom'; adhering to this principle from beginning to end is called 'sincerity.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 大学》所谓的相对重要性是指，根据先天的知识，有一种自然的秩序是不应该被跳过的。这就是 "义"。遵循这个秩序叫做 "礼"。明此序，谓之智。自始至终都遵循这个顺序，就叫做信。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 大学所说的相对重要性，是指按照先天知识，有一个自然的顺序，是不可逾越的。这就是所谓的正义。遵循这个顺序就叫礼。明白这个秩序就称为智慧。而自始至终遵循这个顺序，就叫做忠诚。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 《大学》所谓的亲疏有别，是指根据先天的知识有一个自然的顺序，不应被遗漏。这称为义。遵循这个顺序叫作礼。理解这个顺序叫作智。而从始至终遵循这个顺序叫作信。

text.ori_cn: 〔30〕又曰：“目无体，以万物之色为体；耳无体，以万物之声为体；鼻无体，以万物之臭为体：口无体，以万物之味为体；心无体，以天地万物感之是非为体。”
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “The eye has no substance of its own. Its substance consists of the colors of all things. The ear has no substance of its own. Its substance consists of the sounds of all things. The nose has no substance of its own. 6 Its substance consists of the smells of all things. 7 The mouth has no substance of its own. 8 Its substance consists of the tastes of all things. 9 The mind has no substance of its own. 0 Its substance consists of the right or wrong of the influences and responses of Heaven, Earth, and all things. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [30] also said: "The eye has no body, to the colour of all things as a body; the ear has no body, to the sound of all things as a body; the nose has no body, to the smell of all things as a body: the mouth has no body, to the taste of all things as a body; the heart has no body, to the sense of heaven and earth as a body of right and wrong."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [30] It is also said: "The eyes have no body, taking the color of all things as their body; the ears have no body, taking the sounds of all things as their body; the nose has no body, taking the odor of all things as their body; the mouth has no body, taking the taste of all things as its body "The mind has no body, and its body is the sense of right and wrong among all things in the world."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: It is also said: 'The eyes have no substance; they take the colors of all things as their substance. The ears have no substance; they take the sounds of all things as their substance. The nose has no substance; it takes the scents of all things as its substance. The mouth has no substance; it takes the flavors of all things as its substance. The heart has no substance; it takes the judgments of right and wrong through the experiences of all things in heaven and earth as its substance.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："眼睛没有自己的物质。它的实质由万物的颜色组成。耳朵没有自己的物质。它的实质是万物的声音。鼻子没有自己的物质。6 鼻子的实质是万物的气味。7 口腔没有自己的物质。8 它的实质是万物的味道。9 心灵没有自己的物质。0 其本质包括天地万物的影响和反应的对错。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生说：“眼无实体。它的本质是由万物的颜色组成的。耳朵本身没有实体。它的本体是由一切事物的声音组成的。鼻子没有自己的物质。 6 它的本质是万物的香气。 7 口无实体。 8 它的本质是万物的味道。 9 心没有自己的实体。 0 其实质是天地万物的影响和反应的对错。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“眼睛本身没有实体。它的实体由万物的颜色组成。耳朵本身没有实体。它的实体由万物的声音组成。鼻子本身没有实体。它的实体由万物的气味组成。嘴巴本身没有实体。它的实体由万物的味道组成。心灵本身没有实体。它的实体由天地万物的影响和反应的对错组成。”

text.ori_cn: 〔31〕问：“天寿不贰：”先生曰：“学问功夫，于一切声利、嗜好，俱能脱落殆尽，尚有一种生死念头毫发挂带，便于全体有末融释处。
text.man_en: I asked about “not allowing any doublemindedness regardless of longevity or brevity of life. ” The Teacher said, “In the task of learning, if one is able to get rid of all desires for fame and profit and other interests but still has the least bit of concern over life and death, it means that his mind in its totality is not harmonious or at ease. Ideas of life and death come with life itself and cannot easily be gotten rid of.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [31] asked: "Tianshou not two:" Mr. said: "Learning kung fu, in all the sound and profit, hobbies, can be shed all, there is still a kind of life and death thoughts hair hanging with, to facilitate the whole end of the fusion of the release of the place.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: 〔31〕 Question: "The longevity of life is not two years old." The teacher said: "With knowledge and skill, all the sounds and hobbies can be completely eliminated, and there is still a thought of life and death that is not hanging around, so that the whole body can be dissolved and released.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Question 31: 'Heavenly longevity does not come twice.' The Master said: 'The effort in learning, when it can entirely shed all desires for fame, profit, and personal pleasures, yet still carries the slightest thought of life and death, there remains a part of the whole that has not completely been resolved.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 我问到 "无论长寿还是短命，都不能有二心"。"老师说："在做学问的过程中，如果一个人能够摆脱一切名利欲望和其他利益，但仍然对生死有丝毫的牵挂，这说明他的整个心灵并不和谐，也不自在。生死观念伴随着生命本身，无法轻易摆脱。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 我问“无论生命的长短，都不能有二心”。 ” 先生说：“在学习的过程中，如果能够去掉一切名利之欲和其他利益，但还有一丝生死的顾虑，那就是他的心完整了。不和谐或不自在。生与死的观念是与生命本身相伴而生的，无法轻易摆脱。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 我问了关于“不论寿命长短都不允许有任何双重心态。”老师说：“在学习的过程中，如果一个人能够摆脱对名利和其他利益的所有欲望，但仍然对生死有丝毫的担忧，这意味着他的心完全不和谐或不安。生死观念伴随着生活本身而来，不易摆脱。

text.ori_cn2ggl_en: 〔35〕The teacher said: "Ignorance and omniscience, this is the true nature.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Mr. [35] said, 'To know nothing and to know everything, such is the nature of the original essence.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："[心灵的]本原一无所知，却又无所不知。从一开始就是这样。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 老师说：“本体无知，却又知道一切。从一开始就是这样的。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说，“心的本来面目一无所知，却又无所不知。从一开始就是这样的。

text.ori_cn: 譬如日未尝有心照物，而自无物不照，无照无不照，原是日的本体。
text.man_en: For example, the sun does not purposely shine on anything and yet there is nothing it does not shine on. Not [purposely to] shine and yet shining on everything is characteristic of the original substance of the sun.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: For example, if the sun does not have the heart to illuminate things, but has nothing to illuminate, and has nothing to illuminate, it is the essence of the sun.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: For example, the sun has no intention of illuminating anything, but there is nothing that it does not illuminate. Without illumination, it illuminates everything. It is the essence of the sun.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: For instance, the sun has never deliberately shone upon things, yet there is nothing it does not illuminate. Whether illuminating or not, it is inherent in the nature of the sun.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 例如，太阳不会特意照耀任何东西，但也没有它不照耀的东西。不[特意]照耀却又照耀万物，这就是太阳本原的特征。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 例如，太阳不会刻意照射任何东西，但也没有什么东西是它不照射的。不发光而照万物，这是太阳本体的特征。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 例如，太阳并不是有意地照耀任何事物，但却没有一样东西不被它照耀。不[有意地去]照耀而却照耀所有事物是太阳的本质特性。

text.ori_cn: 良知本无知，今却要有知，本无不知，今却疑有不知，只是信不及耳。”
text.man_en: Innate knowledge originally knows nothing and now we want it to know. Originally it knows everything and now we suspect that there is something it does not know. This is because we have not sufficient confidence in it. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Conscience had no knowledge, but now it wants to have knowledge; it had no knowledge, but now it suspects that it has no knowledge, but it is just not enough to believe."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: A good conscience was originally ignorant, but now he wants to know. He was originally ignorant, but now he doubts that he doesn't know, but he can't believe it. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Original conscience is without knowledge, but now it needs to have knowledge; originally it knew no ignorance, but now doubts whether there is ignorance—it's simply a matter of lacking sufficient faith.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 先天知识原本什么都不知道，现在我们却希望它知道。它原本无所不知，现在我们却怀疑它有什么不知道。这是因为我们对它没有足够的信心。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 天生的知识原本一无所知，现在我们想让它知道。本来它什么都知道，现在我们怀疑有什么东西它不知道。这是因为我们对此没有足够的信心。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 先天本知无所不知，今欲其知；本知无所不知，今疑其未之知。此盖信不足也。

text.ori_cn: 〔36〕先生曰：“‘惟天下之圣，为能聪明睿知’，旧看何等玄妙，今看来原是人人自有的；耳原是聪，目原是明，心思原是睿知，圣人只是一能之尔，能处正是良知。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “Only the perfect sage in the world has quickness of apprehension, intelligence, insight, and wisdom. How deep and mysterious this formerly seemed! But as we look at it today, we realize that these qualities are common to all men. Man's ears are by nature quick of apprehension, his eyes intelligent, and his mind and thought have insight and wisdom. The sage is the only one who can demonstrate them with one effort. 6 What enables him to do so is his innate knowledge,
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [36] Mr. said: "'but the world of the saint, for can be smart Rui Zhi', the old see how subtle, today seems to be everyone own; ear is originally clever, eye is originally clear, mind is originally Rui Zhi, the saint is just a can of the Er, can be exactly conscience.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: 〔36〕 The teacher said: "'Only the sages in the world are wise and wise.' How mysterious it seemed in the past, but now it seems that everyone has it; the ears are originally smart, the eyes are originally bright, and the mind is originally wise. , The saint is just a capable person, and his ability is his conscience.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Mr. (36) said: 'Only the sages of the world possess supreme intelligence and wisdom.' This seemed quite profound in the past, but now I see it as something inherent in everyone. Ears are naturally keen, eyes are naturally sharp, thoughts are naturally wise; a sage is simply one who is able to harness this. The ability lies precisely in one's innate moral consciousness.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："世界上只有完美的圣人才有敏捷的理解力、聪明才智、洞察力和智慧。这在以前看来是多么深奥和神秘！但我们今天看它，就会发现这些品质是所有人都具备的。人的耳朵天生具有敏锐的洞察力，人的眼睛天生具有智慧，人的心灵和思想天生具有洞察力和智慧。只有圣人才能一心一意地展现这些品质。6 使他能够做到这一点的是他与生俱来的知识、
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“天下至圣者，有悟性、聪明、洞察力、智慧。这在以前看来是多么深奥啊！但当我们今天审视它时，我们意识到这些品质是所有男人所共有的。人的耳朵生来敏锐，眼睛生来聪明，心思意念生来有洞察力和智慧。圣人是唯一能够一劳永逸地展示它们的人。 6 使他能够做到这一点的是他与生俱来的知识，
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“世界上只有完美的圣人具有快速的理解力、智慧、洞察力和智慧。这曾经显得多么深奥神秘啊！但今天我们看它时，才意识到这些品质是所有人共有的。人的耳朵天生就具有快速的理解力，眼睛具有智慧，思想和心灵具有洞察力和智慧。圣人是唯一能一次性展示这些品质的人。使他能够做到这一点的是他的天赋知识。”

text.ori_cn: 众人不能，只是个不致知。
text.man_en: and the reason ordinary people cannot do so is that they do not extend their knowledge.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The people can't, it's just a non-knowledge.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Everyone can't, they are just ignorant.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The multitude cannot, it is simply a matter of lack of awareness.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 而普通人之所以做不到这一点，是因为他们没有扩展自己的知识。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 普通人之所以做不到，是因为他们没有扩展自己的知识。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 普通人不能这样做的原因是他们没有拓展他们的知识。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“远虑不是茫茫荡荡去思虑，只是要存这天理。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “To think far ahead does not mean to think and deliberate vaguely and recklessly. It means only to preserve this Principle of Nature.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The gentleman said: "far from worrying is not a vast vast to think about, just to deposit this heavenly reason.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The teacher said: "To be far-sighted is not to think about things in a vague way, but to keep this principle in mind.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'Far-reaching consideration does not mean thinking aimlessly and without direction; it is about upholding the principles of heaven.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："深谋远虑并不意味着胡思乱想。它只意味着维护这一自然原则。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“思远虑，不是胡思乱想。它仅意味着保留这一自然原理。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说，“远虑并非胡思乱想，而是要保存天理。”

text.ori_cn: 天理在人心，亘古亘今，无有终始。
text.man_en: The Principle of Nature is present in the human mind at all times, past and present, and has neither beginning nor end.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The Divine Principle is in the human heart and has no end in sight.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The principles of heaven are in the human heart, from ancient times to the present, without beginning or end.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Moral principles reside in the human heart, enduring through ancient and present times, without beginning or end.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 自然的原则在人类的头脑中始终存在，无论过去还是现在，它既没有开始，也没有结束。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 自然法则无时无刻都存在于人类的心中，无论过去还是现在，无始无终。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 自然的原理始终存在于人类的心灵中，无论过去还是现在，并且没有起点也没有终点。

text.ori_cn: 天理即是良知，千思万虑，只是要致良知。
text.man_en: It is identical with innate knowledge. In our thousands of thoughts and tens of thousands of deliberations, we must only extend innate knowledge.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The Divine Principle is conscience, and a thousand thoughts are just to bring about conscience.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The principle of heaven is the conscience, and all the thoughts and considerations are just to lead to the conscience.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The principle of heaven is exactly conscience; after countless thoughts and considerations, all one seeks is to fully realize this conscience.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 它与先天知识是一致的。在我们的千思万想和数以万计的斟酌中，我们只能扩展先天知识。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 它与先天知识相同。在我们千思万虑中，我们只能扩展先天的知识。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 这与先天的知识是相同的。在我们成千上万的想法和数以万计的思考中，我们只需扩展先天的知识。

text.ori_cn: 良知愈思愈精明，若不精思，漫然随事应去，良知便粗了。
text.man_en: The more innate knowledge thinks, the more refined and clear it becomes. If it does not think carefully but vaguely responds to things as they come, it will become crude.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The more one thinks, the more one's conscience is refined; if one does not think well, if one just goes along with things, one's conscience will be coarse.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The more you think about your conscience, the smarter it becomes. If you don't think carefully and just take things as they happen, your conscience will become rough.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The more one contemplates conscience, the more astute it becomes. If one does not think deeply and merely responds to matters thoughtlessly, conscience becomes coarse.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 先天知识思考得越多，就会变得越精炼、越清晰。如果不认真思考，只是模糊地随遇而安，就会变得粗糙。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先天知识思考得越多，它就越精细和清晰。如果不仔细思考，临到就模糊地反应，就会变得粗暴。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 天赋知识思考得越多，就变得越精细和清晰。如果不仔细思考，而是模糊地应对事情，它就会变得粗糙。

text.ori_cn: 若只着在事上茫茫荡荡去思，叫做远虑，便不免有毁誉、得丧、人欲，搀入其中，就是将迎了。
text.man_en: If, in connection with a thing, one merely thinks vaguely and recklessly, and considers that to be thinking far ahead, then concern about praise or criticism and about gain or loss and other selfish human desires will inevitably enter into his mind and become mixed with it. This is leaning forward or backward to accommodate things.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: If you only think about things in a vague manner, which is called far-sightedness, then you will not be able to avoid ruining reputation, gains and losses, and human desires, which are mixed in, that is, you will be welcomed.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: If you only think about things in a vague and wandering way, which is called long-term thinking, you will inevitably have reputation, gain, loss, and human desires. If you mix them into it, you will be welcomed.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: If one is aimlessly engrossed in thoughts of worldly matters, it is called distant concern. Inevitably, it will be mixed with praise, criticism, gains, losses, and human desires, which is essentially courting trouble.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 如果对一件事，只是空泛地胡思乱想，认为这就是深谋远虑，那么，褒贬、得失等人的私欲就会不可避免地进入他的头脑，与之混为一谈。这就是前俯后仰，迁就事物。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 如果对一件事，只是胡思乱想，认为是想得太远了，那么，关于褒贬、得失等人性的私欲，就必然会进入他的思想之中，并与他的思想混杂在一起。它。这是向前或向后倾斜以适应事物。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 如果在处理一件事情时，只是模糊地和粗心大意地思考，并将其视为深远思考，那么对赞美或批评、得失等自私的个人欲望的担心，必然会进入他的脑海并与之混合。这就是为了适应事物而前倾或后仰。

text.ori_cn: 周公终夜以思，只是‘戒慎不睹，恐惧不闻’的功夫；见得时其气象与将迎自别。”
text.man_en: Duke Chou's thinking about a thing from daytime into the night merely means the effort to be cautious with what is not seen and apprehensive of what is not heard. If we understand this, we will realke that his disposition is quite different from leaning forward or backward. ”
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The Duke of Zhou spends all his nights in thought, but it is only the work of 'caution not to be seen, fear not to be heard'; and when he sees it his weather is different from that which will be welcomed."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Duke of Zhou thought about it all night, but it was just a matter of "being careful not to see it, being afraid not to hear it"; when he saw it, his appearance was different from that of the general. "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Duke Zhou spent the whole night in contemplation, focusing solely on the practice of 'being cautious and vigilant even in unseen matters, and being fearful and aware even in unheard situations'; when he understood it, its essence differed distinctly from that which is anticipated.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 周公 "日有所思，夜有所梦"，就是 "慎其所不见，忧其所不闻"。如果我们理解了这一点，就会发现他的性情与前俯后仰截然不同。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 周公日思夜想，无非就是对未见之事保持谨慎，对未闻之事有所忧虑而已。明白了这一点，我们就会发现，他的性情与前倾、后倾是截然不同的。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 周公昼思夜想，只是在用心对待看不见的和听不到的事。如果我们理解这一点，就会意识到他的态度与前倾后仰是截然不同的。

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“圣贤只是为己之学，重功夫不重效验。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “The learning of the sage and the worthy is for themselves. Its emphasis is on effort and not on effect.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mr said: "Sage is only for their own learning, heavy kung fu is not important to the effect.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "Sages only study for their own sake, and they value hard work rather than results.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'Sages and worthy persons solely pursue self-cultivation, valuing effort over immediate results.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 师曰："圣贤之学，贵在自得。其学重力而不重效。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 子曰：“圣人之学，为己而学。它强调的是努力而不是效果。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“圣贤之学为己。其重在努力，而不在结果。”

text.ori_cn: 仁者以万物为体：不能一体，只是己私未忘。
text.man_en: The man of humanity regards all things as one body. If one fails to achieve this unity, it is because his selfishness has not been eliminated.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The Benevolent One has all things as his body: he cannot be one, but his own selfishness is not forgotten.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: A benevolent person takes all things as his body: they cannot be one, but they have not forgotten their own interests.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The benevolent person regards all things as one body; failure to see all things as one is due to personal selfishness not being forgotten.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 人类视万物为一体。如果一个人不能实现这种统一，那是因为他的自私还没有消除。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 人类视一切事物为一个整体。如果一个人达不到这种统一，那是因为他的私心还没有消除。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 仁者视万物为一体。如果不能达到这种统一，是因为他的自私没有被消除。

text.ori_cn: 全得仁体，则天下皆归于吾仁，就是八荒皆在我闼意：天下皆与；其仁亦在其中。
text.man_en: If the true nature of humanity is preserved, then all under heaven will come under this humanity, or ‘The whole universe is inside my room!' [What Chu Hsi understood as] the entire world sharing one's humanity is included in it.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: If you have fully attained the body of benevolence, then all the world will return to my benevolence, that is, all the eight worlds will be in my room: all the world will be with; and its benevolence will be in it.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: If you fully acquire the body of benevolence, then all the world will return to my benevolence, and all the eight wastelands will be in my heart: all the world will be with me, and my benevolence will also be in it.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: If all virtues are fully possessed, then the whole world will be drawn to my benevolence. This means that the eight directions are within my gateway: the whole world is unified; and benevolence is found within this unity.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 如果保留了人性的本真，那么天下万物都将归于这种人性，或者说'整个宇宙都在我的房间里！'[朱熹的理解是]整个世界都在分享一个人的人性。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 如果保留了人性的本性，那么天下都将归于人性之下，或者说“整个宇宙都在我的房间里”。朱熹所理解的，整个人性的世界都包含在其中。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 如果保存了人性的真正本质，那么天下万物将处于这种人性之下，或‘全宇宙都在我的房间里！’[朱熹所理解的]整个世界共享一种人性也包含在其中。

text.ori_cn: 如‘在邦无怨，在家无怨’，亦只是自家不怨，如‘不怨天，不尤人’之意；然家邦无怨于我，亦在其中，但所重不在此。”
text.man_en: For example, "I have no complaints against my country, and I have no complaints at home. " It also means that I don't have any complaints against myself, just like "I don't blame God, I don't blame others. " "
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: If 'there is no grudge in the state, there is no grudge at home,' it is only the self that is not grudging, as in the sense of 'not grudging heaven, not grudging others'; but the state of the family that is not grudging to me is also included in it, but the emphasis is not on this."
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: For example, "I have no complaints against my country, and I have no complaints at home." It also means that I don't have any complaints against myself, just like "I don't blame God, I don't blame others." "
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: For instance, 'No resentment in the state, no resentment at home' simply means one does not harbor resentment oneself, similar to the notion of 'not blaming heaven, not blaming others'; however, the state and home not resenting me is also included, but that is not the main focus.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 例如，"我对国家没有怨言，对家庭也没有怨言。"这也意味着我对自己没有任何怨言，就像 "我不怨天，不尤人。" "
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 比如“我对祖国没有什么怨言，对家里我也没有什么怨言”，这也意味着我对自己没有什么怨言，就像“我不怨天尤人，我不怨天尤人”一样。其他的。 ” ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 例如，"我对我的国家没有怨言，我在家里也没有怨言。" 这也意味着我对自己没有任何怨言，就像“我不怪天，我不怪人。”

text.ori_cn: 〔39〕问：“孟子‘巧力圣智’之说，朱子云：‘三子力有余而巧不足。
text.man_en: [39] Question: "Mencius's theory of "Qiaoli Shengzhi", Zhu Zi said: "The three sons have more than enough skill but not enough skill. "
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: [39] Q.: "Mencius' statement of 'the holy wisdom of skillfulness,' Zhu Zi said: 'The three sons have more than enough force but less than enough skillfulness.'
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: [39] Question: "Mencius's theory of "Qiaoli Shengzhi", Zhu Zi said: "The three sons have more than enough skill but not enough skill."
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: [39] Question: 'Mencius' saying of 'skill, strength, sage, and wisdom', Zhu Xi said: 'The three had more strength than skill.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: [39] 问题"孟子 "的 "巧立名目 "说，朱子说："三子有余而技不足。"
text.man_en2ggl_cn: [39]问：“孟子的‘巧力生智’论，朱子曰：‘三子，技有余而技不足。 ”
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 问题：“孟子的‘巧力胜智’理论，朱子说：‘三子有余巧而不足智。’

text.ori_cn: 先生曰：“三子固有力亦有巧。
text.man_en: The Teacher said, “The three gentlemen, of course, had strength. But they also had skill.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Mr said: "The three sons inherent force and also have a clever.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: The Master said: "The three sons have inherent strength and skill.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: The gentleman said, 'The three of you indeed possess both strength and skill.'
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 老师说："三位先生当然有力气。但他们也有技巧。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 先生说：“三位先生当然有实力。但他们也有技巧。
text.man_en2gpt_cn: 老师说：“这三位先生，当然有力量。但他们也有技巧。”

text.ori_cn: 巧、力实非两事，巧亦只在用力处，力而不巧，亦是徒力。
text.man_en: Strength and skill are not two different things. Skill is found only in the application of strength and strength without skill will be in vain.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: Coercion and strength are not two separate things; coercion is only in the place of exertion; strength without coercion is also futile.
text.ori_cn2ggl_en: Skill and strength are not two different things. Skill only lies in exertion. Strength without skill is also in vain.
text.ori_cn2gpt_en: Skill and strength are not two separate things. Skill lies in the application of strength, and exerting strength without skill is merely wasted effort.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 力量和技巧并非两回事。只有在力量的运用中才能找到技巧，没有技巧的力量将是徒劳的。

text.ori_cn: 三子譬如射，一能步箭，一能马箭，一能远箭，他射得到俱谓之力，中处俱可谓之巧；但步不能马，马不能远，各有所长，便是才力分限有不同处。
text.man_en: The three gentlemen may be compared to archers. One can shoot while walking, one on horseback, and one from a great distance. If they all reach the mark, they may be said to have strength, and if they hit the mark, they may be said to have skill. But the one able to shoot while walking may not be able to do so on horseback and the one able to do so on horseback may not be able to do so from a great distance. Each has his own proficiency. 6 This is where they differ in the amount and limit of their ability.
text.ori_cn2dpl_en: The three sons, for example, shooting, one can step arrow, one can horse arrow, one can far arrow, he shoots to get all the so-called power, in the place can be called clever; but step can not horse, horse can not be far, each has its own strengths, that is, the talent is limited to have a different place.

If they hit the target, it can be said they possess strength, and if they hit the center, it can be said they possess skill. However, one who shoots on foot cannot shoot on horseback, and one who shoots on horseback cannot shoot long distances. Each has their own strengths, highlighting the different limitations of their abilities.
text.man_en2dpl_cn: 三位先生可以比作弓箭手。一位可以边走边射，一位可以骑马射，一位可以从很远的地方射。如果他们都能射中，就可以说他们有力量；如果他们都能射中，就可以说他们有技巧。但是，能在走路时射击的人不一定能在马背上射击，能在马背上射击的人不一定能在很远的地方射击。各人有各人的熟练程度。6 这就是他们能力的大小和限度的不同之处。

text.ori_cn: 〔40〕先生曰：“‘先天而天弗违’，天即真知也。

text.ori_cn: 〔42〕“圣人之知，如青天之日，贤人如浮云天日，愚人如阴霾天日，虽有昏明不同，其能辨黑白则一。
text.man_en: [The Teacher said, ] “The knowledge of the sage is comparable to the sun in the clear sky, that of the worthy to the sun in the sky with floating clouds, and that of the stupid person to the sun on a dark, dismal day. Although the three kinds of knowledge differ in darkness or clearness, they are the same in the fact that they can distinguish between black and white.

text.ori_cn: 比如日光，亦不可指着力方所，一隙通明，皆是日光所在：虽云雾四塞：太虚中色象可辨，亦是日光不灭处：不可以云能蔽日，教天不要生云。
text.man_en: Take, for example, sunlight. We cannot pin it down to any definite direction or place. When even a small crack is penetrated by the brightness of the sun, sunlight is located there. Although clouds and fog fill all space, color and form in the Great Vacuity can still be distinguished. This also shows that sunlight cannot be obliterated. Simply because clouds can obscure the sun, we should not on that account tell heaven not to produce any cloud.

text.man_en2dpl_cn: 以阳光为例。我们无法将其归结为任何明确的方向或地点。当太阳的光辉穿透哪怕是一条细小的缝隙时，阳光就在那里。虽然云雾弥漫了整个空间，但大虚空中的色彩和形态依然可以分辨。这也说明，阳光是无法被遮蔽的。我们不能因为云雾可以遮蔽阳光，就告诉上天不要产生任何云雾。
text.man_en2ggl_cn: 以阳光为例。我们无法将其固定在任何明确的方向或地点。即使是一条小裂缝被太阳的亮度穿透时，阳光就位于那里。虚空虽有云雾弥漫，但大虚中的色色仍可辨别。这也说明阳光是无法被抹杀的。仅仅因为云会遮挡太阳，我们不应该因此告诉天堂不要产生任何云。
